Robert Neil Proctor

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/7625002991057164
  • Última atualização do currículo em 10/02/2015

Possui graduação em Physics pela Imperial College, London(1980) e doutorado em Astrophysics pela University of Central Lancashire(2002). Atualmente é Revisor de periódico da Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Print) e Revisor de periódico da The Astronomical Journal (New York, N.Y.). Tem experiência na área de Astronomia, com ênfase em Astrofísica Extragalactica. (Texto gerado automaticamente pela aplicação CVLattes)

Linhas de pesquisa
1.
The 2-D kinematic structure of galaxies
Objetivo: The introduction of Integral Field Units (IFUs; e.g. the SAURON instrument)on several large telescopes has recently made possible the study of the kinematics of galaxies in 2 dimensions. This allows the definition and measurement of several important parameters in 2-D, which has proven to be a major advance. For example, the SAURON team have defined the parameter (a surface integral of the angular momentum divided by the kinematic energy). This parameter has proven to be a powerful discriminator between fast and slow rotating early-type galaxies, which show significant differences in their kinematic structures, despite their near identical photometric morphologies. However, IFUs are to-date generally confined to observing the central regions of galaxies (<1 Reff ).They therefore only cover 50% of baryonic mass, 5% of total mass and 10% of total angular momentum. This severely limits the utility of these data in probing the formation histories of galaxies. In a project initiated in 2008, I developed a technique that extracts the galaxy halo light from MOS observations of objects in the halos of nearby early-type galaxies out to very large galacto-centric radii. The technique permits the measurement of the kinematic parameters (recession velocity, velocity and Gauss-Hermite coefficients h3 and h4) of the host galaxy halos out to 3 Reff and beyond. Research in this area continues in a collaboration with Swinburne University and the University of California, Santa Cruz. .
Palavras-chave: Galactic Kinematics; Galaxies.
2.
The nature of fossil groups
Objetivo: The structure and formation of galaxy groups has become a highly topical area of current re- search, as, in the hierarchical build up the cold dark matter picture, they are the main building blocks of larger structures such as galaxy clusters. One particularly interesting class of galaxy group is the so-called Fossil Group (FG). Fossil groups are defined as groups of galaxies in which the brightest, and generally central, galaxy (BCG) is at least two magnitudes brighter than the next brightest galaxy within half the virial radius of the group. To qualify as a fossil the group must also exhibit a high X-ray luminosity. These systems therefore resemble isolated galaxies in the optical, but exhibit group-scale X-ray halos. Until relatively recently, the commonly accepted paradigm for the formation of FGs was that they are ancient systems that have remained undisturbed (i.e. no major in-fall events) since their initial burst of galaxy formation about 8-10 Gyr ago. They represent, therefore, almost pristine examples of the components from which all larger galaxy groups and clusters were assembled - which explains the current interest in them. The physical process governing their formation is thought to be dynamical friction which, over cosmological time, causes massive galaxies in the central regions of the groups to loose angular momentum and spiral inward, ultimately to merge with the central BCGs. This leaves a single, bright, relatively isolated galaxy in the place of the once extant group (and hence the name fossil group). However, in a recent paper by the applicant, this scenario was called into doubt, as results indicated properties inconsistent the current consensus. A fuller, deeper analysis of this issue continues in a collaboration with Renato Dupke of the Observatorio Nacional and Cluadia Mendes de Oliveira at the University of Sao Paulo..
Palavras-chave: Galaxies; Environment of galaxies; Galaxy groups and clusters.
3.
The stellar populations of galaxies and globular clusters
Objetivo: The parameters of interest in the study of "stellar populations" are the age, metallicity and alpha-element abundance ratio of composite stellar populations (such as galaxies and globular clusters). Derived from the integrated light, these parameters give insights into the star formation history of the objects in question. Stellar population analysis has been the subject of much research effort for at least the last two decades - the main motivation being the unraveling of the poorly understood process of galaxy formation. However, these measurement are severely hampered by the age-metallicity degeneracy . This can be summarised by the observation that the integrated spectral energy distributions of old, metal-poor stellar populations are remarkably similar to those of young, metal rich stellar populations. This degeneracy makes the accurate determination of stellar population parameters from broad band photometric observations very challenging. However, the early 1990s saw the publishing of the first sets of models of relatively high resolution spectroscopic indices that utilised the varying sensitivity of specific absorption features to age and metallicity to break this degeneracy. These absorption features are referred to as Lick indices . The models were provided in the form of Single stellar populations which represent a population of stars that all formed at the same time, and from the same gas (i.e. the same metals contents), for comparison to obsrevations My research in this area has focused on the development of use of Lick indices and related kinematic parameters to study the structure and star formation histories of galaxies and globular cluster systems. I have performed analyses of both globular cluster and galaxy data from a large range of sources. Papers published include detailed studies of individual objects, analysis of small targeted samples, as well as the analysis of data from large-scale surveys. .
Palavras-chave: Stellar populations; Galaxies; Galaxy kinematics.


Projetos de pesquisa
2010 - Atual
J-PAS
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Renato de Alencar Dupke em 28/05/2013.
Descrição: I am a (nominally Brazilian) member of the J-PAS project. This project is of crucial importance for the Brazilian astronomy, involving more than 25 institutions and more than 7 in Brazil, including the National Observatory, the Brazilian Center for Physical Research, National Laboratory of Astronomy, and the National Institute for Space Research of the MCT. It is the largest Brazilian project of active participation (50% of the Collaboration Board and the Science Working Groups) Brazilian investments with FINEP, FAPERJ, FAPESP, ON, USP reaching more than 5 million dollars so far focused on building the second largest astronomical camera in the world, JPCam by Brazil. This multi-purpose survey will utilise a completely new and innovative technique to obtain spectra of galaxies and globular clusters. These data will provide not only aa opportunity to probe the stellar population properties of galaxies in a new and completely novel way, but also provide unique insights to the modelling process upon which this branch of research depend so heavily. This makes the J-PAS project the likely source of the next major adavnce in this field. Work that I have already performed on simulated data (real data become available later this year) have already begun to reveal the challenges and confirm the opportunities that these data will afford for stellar population analysis. I am also involved with the galaxy groups and clusters research group within the J-PAS collaboration. .
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Robert Neil Proctor - Integrante / DUPKE, RENATO - Coordenador / MENDES DE OLIVEIRA, C. - Integrante.
2008 - 2010
GAMA survey
Descrição: The Galaxy And Mass Assembly survey is one of the largest multi-wavelenght studies of galaxies in the nearby universe. My responsibilities included redshift estimation of a sub-set of the survey data..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Robert Neil Proctor - Coordenador / The GAMA team - Integrante.
2004 - 2011
The 6dF Galaxy Redshift Survey
Descrição: I was responsible for extracting stellar population parameters from data supplied by the 6dFGRS carried out by the Anglo-Australian Observatory. Results include measurements of the trends between age, metallicity and abundance ratios in nearby early type galaxies and their effects on the observed "fundamental plane" of galaxies..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Doutorado: (7) .

Integrantes: Robert Neil Proctor - Integrante / JONES, D. H. - Integrante / SPRINGOB, CHRISTOPHER M. - Integrante / MAGOULAS, CHRISTINA - Integrante / COLLESS, MATTHEW - Coordenador / CAMPBELL, LACHLAN - Integrante / LUCEY, JOHN - Integrante / MOULD, JEREMY - Integrante / COUCH, WARRICK - Integrante.
2003 - Atual
The properties of Galaxy Groups
Descrição: In this project we are in investigating the nature and properties of galaxy groups - with special focus on two special types; Hickson Compact groups and Fossil groups. The project consists of 3 sub-projects 1) We have utilised Brazilian time on the multi-object spectroscope on the Blanco telescope to probe the stellar populations in Hickson Compact groups down to so-far unsurpassed depth - thus providing, for the first time, statistics suitable for the comparison to "normal;" groups. This will form part of the Ph.D thesis of Universtity of Sao Paulo student Carlos Eduardo Barbosa. 2) After publishing a paper questioning the consensus model for the formation of fossil groups, we are undertaking a much larger and more precise analysis using newly available survey data. This analysis is also being performed by a University of Sao Paulo Student. 3) It is intended that J-PAS data (see J-PAS project) also be folded into our analysis, with the aim to producing what could potentially be the largest study of its type to-date. This would provide innumerable insights into the history and structure of galaxy groups. .
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Doutorado: (3) .

Integrantes: Robert Neil Proctor - Coordenador / MENDES DE OLIVEIRA, CLAUDIA - Integrante / DUPKE, RENATO - Integrante / Carlos Eduardo Barbosa - Integrante / Luiz Azanha - Integrante.

Full Employment History

                             Sao Paulo, Brazil                                   in astrophysics.

                             Melbourne, Australia                              in astrophysics.

                              Preston, Lancs, UK                               Ph.D. student.

                             Paignton, Devon, UK                             project manager.

1990-1992            Voluntary Services Overseas (VSO)  Voluntary teacher
                              London, UK                                          in St. Kitts, W.I.

Grants Gained
- In the final year of my Ph.D I gained a Royal Society Fellowship to be held at Swinburne.
- I was the recipient of an ARC Linkage International Fellowship.
- I was awarded funding of AU$5000 by the University of Central Lancashire in the UK for a one month collaborative visit.
- In March 2009 I was awarded a two year FAPESP fellowship to be carried out at USP, Brazil which was extended until February 2013.
- In July 2012 I was awarded a grant to participate in the University of Birmingham Visiting Fellows Scheme
